hints_html:
The line is an intersection of two planes and so by definition it is on both planes. What is the relationship to any point on a plane and its normal?

As an alternative method, how can we re-write this problem as a matrix problem?

question: A 16
sols_html:
The first plane

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}y-z=1\end{aligned}\]

has normal n\(_1\)=[0,1,-1] (just the coefficients on x,y,z). The second plane

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}2x+y+z=2\end{aligned}\]

has normal n\(_2\)=[2,1,1]. Let’s call the direction our line has v. Notice that since v is an intersection of the two planes then by definition it is on plane 1 and plane 2. Therefore

\[\begin{aligned} \mathbf{n}_1\times\mathbf{v}=\mathbf{0} \quad\text{and}\quad \mathbf{n}_2\times\mathbf{v}=\mathbf{0}.\end{aligned}\]

Therefore we seek v so that it is orthogonal to both normal vectors. The cross product, by definition, provides this direction. Therefore,

\[\begin{aligned} \mathbf{v}=\mathbf{n}_1\times\mathbf{n}_2=[0,1,-1]\times[2,1,1]=[2,-2,-2].\end{aligned}\]

We want this to have length 1 and so we see that

\[\begin{aligned} |\mathbf{v}|=\sqrt{12}=2\sqrt{3}.\end{aligned}\]

Therefore we get that the unit norm vector, \(\mathbf{\hat{v}}\) is

\[\begin{aligned} \mathbf{\hat{v}}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}[1,-1,-1].\end{aligned}\]

Since a vector on the line has to be on each plane, it has to be a solution of a linear system. We have the following equations

\[\begin{aligned} \left\{ \begin{aligned} y-z&=1\\ 2x+y+z&=2 \end{aligned}\right.\end{aligned}\]

which is a linear system with 2 equations in 3 unknowns. We can write it in an augmented matrix as

\[\begin{aligned} \left[\begin{array}{ccc|c} 0 & 1 & -1 & 1\\ 2 & 1 & 1 & 2 \end{array}\right]\end{aligned}\]

We will swap the first two rows and then row reduce to get

\[\begin{aligned} \left[\begin{array}{ccc|c} 1 & 0 & 1 & 1/2\\ 0 & 1 & -1 & 1 \end{array}\right].\end{aligned}\]

We notice there is a free variable and we let x = t. We then get

\[\begin{aligned} z&=\frac{1}{2}-t\\ y&=1+z=\frac{3}{2}-t\end{aligned}\]

Therefore we get that the solution, s, is

\[\begin{aligned} \mathbf{s}=\mathbf{s}_0+t\mathbf{v}=\left[0,\frac{3}{2},\frac{1}{2}\right]+t[1,-1,-1].\end{aligned}\]

The direction part of the line, v is [1,-1,-1]. However to make it length 1 we must divide by its magnitude, \(|\mathbf{v}|=\sqrt{3}\) to get,

\[\begin{aligned} \mathbf{\hat{v}}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}[1,-1,-1]\end{aligned}\]

just like in solution 1.

statement_html:
Find a vector of length \(1\) that is parallel to the line given by the equations

\[\begin{aligned} \left\{ \begin{aligned} y-z &= 1 \\ 2x+y+z &= 2 \end{aligned}\right.\end{aligned}\]
statement_raw:
Find a vector of length <math>1</math> that is parallel to the line given by the equations

:<math>
\left\{ \begin{align} y-z &= 1 \\ 2x+y+z &= 2 \end{align}\right.
</math>
